node.title: Amid Virus Surge, Salzburg Festival Announces Next Summer
node.description: Classical music’s most storied annual event will return to prepandemic scale, with more than 200 events over six weeks.

node.title: Prosecution Rests at Ghislaine Maxwell Trial After 4th Accuser Testifies
node.description: Annie Farmer was 16 when, she said, Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell engaged in behavior that upset her.

node.title: Iran’s Nuclear Program Ignites New Tension Between U.S. and Israel
node.description: Strains emerged during talks this week after a short period of strong relations between a new Israeli government and new American one.

node.title: Jan. 6 Committee Examines PowerPoint Document Sent to Meadows
node.description: Mark Meadows’s lawyer said the former White House chief of staff did not act on the document, which recommended that President Donald J. Trump declare a national emergency to keep himself in power.

node.title: Despite Austria’s virus surge, Salzburg Festival announces a program for next summer.
node.description: By Zachary Woolfe

node.title: Minnesota Bank Manager John Askwith Has Black Man Who Tried to Cash Paycheck Handcuffed
node.description: "I was handcuffed...people were looking...like I'm a criminal or something," the man, Joe Morrow said of the incident.

node.title: Colorado's Dem Gov. Jared Polis Says Masks No Longer Needed as New York Enacts Mandate
node.description: Polis said he didn't hesitate to issue a statewide mask mandate when COVID-19 first emerged, but now "the emergency is over," he said.

node.title: Proud Boys Member Alan Swinney Gets 10 Years in Prison for Violent Actions at Protests
node.description: Swinney sentenced to 10 years in prison on convictions for 11 charges for use of mace on protestors, pointing a firearm at others and several more infractions.

node.title: Fowl Play: Homeowners Association's Botched Geese Removal Attempt Led to 10 Birds Drowning
node.description: Rolando Calzadilla, who owns a pest removal company, said he gave the geese bread laced with sedatives, but a loud car startled the birds.

node.title: Despite Rise in Smash-and-Grabs, These Major Cities Saw Robberies Drop in 2021
node.description: Chicago, San Francisco and Baltimore are among the cities with fewer reported robberies in 2021 than in 2020.

node.title: As Inflation Soars China Trolls US for Disparity Between the 1 Percent and Rest of America
node.description: The trolling occurred in a Chinese report entitled "Ten Questions for American Democracy".

node.title: Matthew Ray Hancock Dons Clown Mask, Says He Has Bomb in Limo at Las Vegas Airport: Police
node.description: A man was arrested for driving a limo through security gates at a Las Vegas airport while wearing a clown mask and telling police he had a "bomb" in the car.

node.title: Realiti Courson Sues Deputies She Says Fired Rubber Bullets at Her During Panic Attack
node.description: "Caged dogs are afforded better treatment than Realiti was given when she was shocked and shot while caged in a cell," the lawsuit says.

node.title: U.S. scraps plan to end court agreement protecting migrant children
node.description: For decades, the Flores settlement has allowed non-profit lawyers to inspect government facilities housing migrant children.

node.title: Ex-Proud Boys Member Gets 10 Years in Prison for Violence at Portland Protests
node.description: Prosecutors called Alan Swinney, 51, a “white nationalist vigilante cowboy” who shot a man in the eye with a paintball gun.

node.title: 24 Indicted in Georgia Case That Feds Call Modern-Day Slavery With Over 100 Migrants Freed
node.description: Police broke up a criminal enterprise that made $200 million by abusing the H-2A visa program that brought migrant workers into the U.S.

node.title: Salvation Army's Popularity Takes a Hit When Tied to Its Anti-Racism Campaign, Poll Finds
node.description: A recent survey by Rasmussen shows a decline in The Salvation Army's reputation since introducing its "Let's Talk About Racism" initiative.

node.title: This week on "Face the Nation," December 12, 2021
node.description: New Hampshire Governor Chris Sununu and New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy appear on "Face the Nation" Sunday.

node.title: N.C.A.A. Follows Familiar Pattern in Punishment for Auburn
node.description: In a case of corruption in men’s basketball, the N.C.A.A. largely accepted penalties Auburn imposed on itself after a former assistant coach funneled money to players.

node.title: Small Court Victories Change Nothing for Women Seeking Abortions in Texas
node.description: A Texas statute that bans abortion after six weeks of pregnancy was seemingly undercut by two court rulings, but the reality on the ground has not changed.

node.title: Bob Dole Remembered For Quips That Would 'Let The Air Out of The Partisan Balloons'
node.description: Dole's funeral was held at Washington National Cathedral and the World War II Memorial Friday with dozens of current and former politicians in attendance.

node.title: As Texas Law Is Upheld, Providing Abortion Pills by Mail Can Lead to Steep Fines, Jail
node.description: Women in Texas most commonly terminate their pregnancies by receiving medical abortions, according to state data.

node.title: U.S. Diplomat Meets With Citgo 6 in Venezuela in Effort to Secure Their Release
node.description: Roger Carstens told the six executives that he had a discussion with Maduro government officials regarding the case but didn't identify who they were.

node.title: Jan. 6 Committee Subpoenas Six More, Including Those it Says Helped Organize Trump Rallies
node.description: Leaders of the "Stop the Steal" movement and Moms for America were along those subpoenaed Friday.

node.title: Harry Potter first edition sells for record smashing $471,000
node.description: A first edition of Harry Potter has sold for $471,000 in the United States in what the auctioneers said was a world record price for a 2Oth century work of fiction.

node.title: Why Apps Suddenly Want to Protect Kids
node.description: New British guidelines are influencing what U.S. internet companies do to protect American children.

node.title: G.M.’s electric vehicle efforts reportedly include a bigger presence in Michigan.
node.description: The company will make electric pickups at an existing plant and batteries at a factory built with a partner, a person with knowledge of the plan said.

node.title: Who Can Be Called an Astronaut? The F.A.A. Will No Longer Say.
node.description: Starting in January, space tourists will not receive a participation trophy for flying to space. But everyone will be on the honor roll.

node.title: Company Faces Almost $400,000 Fine For Knowingly Exposing Employees to Arsenic
node.description: U.S. Minerals has to pay $393,200 and be under probation after ignoring years of warnings against exposing employees to arsenic.

node.title: Biden 'Deeply Troubled' by Reports Kellogg's May Permanently Replace 1,400 Striking Workers
node.description: "Permanently replacing striking workers is an existential attack on the union and its members' jobs and livelihoods," said Biden.
